conclusion: To find the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
For particle A, the deceleration phase is from t = t_0 to t = 3t_0.
For particle B, the deceleration phase is from t = 5t_0 to t = 6t_0.
Initial velocity for particle A at t = t_0 is 2v_0.
Final velocity for particle A at t = 3t_0 is 0.
Time interval for particle A is 2t_0.
Acceleration a_A is -v_0/t_0 for particle A.
Initial velocity for particle B at t = 5t_0 is v_0.
Final velocity for particle B at t = 6t_0 is 0.
Time interval for particle B is t_0.
Acceleration a_B is -v_0/t_0 for particle B.
The magnitude of acceleration for A is v_0/t_0.
The magnitude of acceleration for B is v_0/t_0.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration is 1.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1.
